div1.p: A review of Havard's book on military hygiene comments on its more comprehensive treatment of infectious diseases and sanitary methods than the first edition. [Courtesy of The Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia Library]

div1.head: Review: Havard's Military Hygiene, 2nd Ed., 1914, [June, 1914]
div1.p:
Preventive Medicine is at present a rapidly progressing
branch of medical science, and much water has flowed by the
mill in the five years since the appearance of Havard's Mil-
itary Hygiene. Students of military sanitation will welcome
therefore the appearance of the second edition. Colonel Havard
has brought to this work unusual scholarship and the ripe ex-
perience of nearly forty years of active military service, and
he has followed closely the progress of hygiene, particularly
in its applications to the conditions of military life. The
result has been an increase of 300 pages in his book, and
while the student, like the lover, regrets to see a favorite
grow stout, the enlargement has been in this case deftly con-
cealed by the arts of the publisher, so that it has not caused
any gain in bulk or weight.

Especially noticeable is the fuller treatment of the in-
fectious diseases. It is gratifying for example to find measles
which did not appear in the first edition, recognized as an im-
portant disease of military life, especially among raw troops.
It is easier to accept new facts than to make applications of
them, which upset well established points of view. It is dif-
ficult for us to realize, that a case of yellow fever or bubon-
ic plague is as harmless to those coming in contact with it, as
one of malaria or a broken leg. It is thus very creditable
to the scientific spirit of the author, that he accepts frankly,
as do the great majority of practical sanitarians, the views
of Chapin as to the uselessness of terminal disinfections, and
the unimportance of formites in the transmission of the common
zymotic diseases. If he seems to incline toward the old retual-
istic fumigations in the case of scarlet fever, it is in company
with most medical authorities, who seem slow to realize, that
the time honored belief in the clinging infectivity of this dis-
ease in clothing and apartments is based on evidence of the same
a priori character and no whit better than that advanced a decade
or more ago by our southern confreres, to support their convic-
tion of the transmission of yellow fever in the same way.

The chapters which deal with the subjects of general sanit-
ary interest, such as food, water, ventilation and the disposal
of wastes are of satisfying fullness and clarity, and entirely
up to date. The treatment of the subject of ventilation is of
interest, because the recent work in this subject of Hill,
Haldane, Hough and others has been so destructive of our old
ideas and standards as to sweep us from our morings&leave us
drifting with only the wet bulb thermometer for a compass. It
is handled with much conservatism and at the same time a due
recognition of the newer work, so that the reader has a comfor-
table feeling of being on solid ground. But the peculiar value
of the book lies in its treatment of the special conditions of
military life and particularly of the soldier in camp and upon
the march. Here the authors experience with troops in the four
quarters of our country, in the tropics and with the great ar-
mies of Manchuria imparts a freshness and vitality to his
style and a solidity to his conclusions, which are given only
to the man who has come by long service to know the way of the
army.

Havard Mil Hygiene
